metadata.case_name: M/s. Kirloskar Oil Engines Ltd. v. Bibawe

facts.text: Respondent Bibawe made an application to the Industrial Tribunal at Bombay under s.33A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, alleging employment by appellant as watchman since July 21, 1958, and becoming permanent workman.
On May 15, 1960, Security Officer of appellant orally discharged respondent from service.
At time of discharge, an industrial dispute was pending between appellant and its employees before Industrial Tribunal.
Appellant denied respondent was its employee; services made available via police scheme for supplying watchmen to employers.

Scheme: Private employers apply to District Superintendent of Police (D.S.P.); D.S.P. supplies watchman if available; employer pays monthly pay in advance to Watchman Fund; Rs.5/8/- deducted for clothing; balance paid to watchman by police.

Under scheme, police supervises watchmen (night patrols, musters); watchmen under departmental control of D.S.P., who can fine/punish; employers cannot; employer gives fortnight's notice to dispense services.
Industrial Tribunal held s.33 contravened, ordered reinstatement with full back wages from discharge date.
Respondent took uniform from Police Office; filled form on joining; applied to appellant for leaves (disputed); interviewed by Police Jamadar; Mr. Pansare (police) checked work quality.

Mr. Chorpade (Sub-inspector) evidence: Leaves sanctioned by police; Jamadar supervises; muster roll at police station; D.S.P. fixes pay, withdraws/transfers watchmen; police checks and withdraws if unsatisfactory.
Uniform per Police Manual Rule 426; watchmen given buckle no.; cannot be worn by private persons.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent was employee/workman of appellant such that discharge contravened s.33 during pending industrial dispute.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent not employee per scheme terms and oral evidence; s.33 not contravened; s.33A application incompetent.

respondent_arguments.text: Discharge contravened s.33 as respondent was permanent employee/watchman of appellant during pending dispute.
Test from Shivnandan Sharma: Appellant directed how work to be done, so employer.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme terms show no master-servant relation: Police pays, controls, supervises, disciplines; employer pays fund, cannot punish; D.S.P. has master's powers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent cannot be treated as appellant's employee despite working as watchman.

court_reasoning.text: Oral evidence corroborates scheme: Police handles uniform, leaves, supervision, muster, withdrawal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence inconsistent with employment by appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Shivnandan Sharma test (who directs work) not decisive universally; depends on all facts; inapplicable here per scheme.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No single test; gardeners/watchmen example shows direction alone insufficient.

holdings.text: Respondent not employee of appellant; no contravention of s.33; Tribunal erred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for employer-employee relation depend on facts; 'direction of work' test not universally decisive.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Approval required for discharge of workman during pending dispute; application lies if contravened.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal's order of reinstatement with back wages set aside as respondent not appellant's employee.

key_quotes.text: "the relationship of master and servant did not subsist between the two."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the decision of the question as to the relationship of employer and employee must be determined in the light of all relevant facts and circumstances"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects single-test approach for master-servant relation.

key_quotes.text: "Who is the paymaster, who can dismiss... the most satisfactory... is to ask who is entitled to tell the employee the way in which he is to do the work"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoted from precedent but distinguished as not decisive here.
